pli-tv-bu-vb-pj2:7.44.1: Being afraid of wrongdoing, the monks did not take any equipment to the observance-day hall or to meetings, and they sat down on the bare ground.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pj2:7.44.2: They became dirty, as did their robes.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pj2:7.45.1: On one occasion at Campā, a nun who was a pupil of the nun Thullanandā went to a family that supported Thullanandā and said,
pli-tv-bu-vb-pj2:7.45.2: “The Venerable wants to drink the threefold pungent rice-porridge.”
pli-tv-bu-vb-pj2:7.45.3: When it was ready, she took it away and ate it herself.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pj2:7.45.4: When Thullanandā found out about this, she accused her, saying,
pli-tv-bu-vb-pj2:7.45.8: who in turn told the monks,
pli-tv-bu-vb-pj2:7.45.11: but there’s an offense entailing confession for lying in full awareness.”
pli-tv-bu-vb-pj2:7.45.12: On one occasion in Rājagaha, a nun who was a pupil of the nun Thullanandā went to a family that supported Thullanandā and said,
pli-tv-bu-vb-pj2:7.45.13: “The Venerable wants to eat a honey-ball.”
pli-tv-bu-vb-pj2:7.45.14: When it was ready, she took it away and ate it herself.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pj2:7.45.15: When Thullanandā found out about this, she accused her, saying,
pli-tv-bu-vb-pj2:7.45.19: but there’s an offense entailing confession for lying in full awareness.”
pli-tv-bu-vb-pj2:7.46.1: At one time in Vesāli, a householder who was a supporter of Venerable Ajjuka had two children living with him, a son and a nephew.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pj2:7.46.3: “Sir, please assign this estate to the one of these two boys who has faith and confidence.”
pli-tv-bu-vb-pj2:7.46.4: It turned out that the householder’s nephew had faith and confidence, and so Ajjuka assigned that estate to him.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pj2:7.46.5: He then established a household with that wealth and made a gift.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pj2:7.46.6: That householder’s son then said to Venerable Ānanda,
pli-tv-bu-vb-pj2:7.46.7: “Venerable Ānanda, who is the father’s heir, the son or the nephew?”
pli-tv-bu-vb-pj2:7.46.9: “Sir, this Venerable Ajjuka has assigned our wealth to our housemate.”
pli-tv-bu-vb-pj2:7.46.10: “Venerable Ajjuka is no longer an ascetic.”
pli-tv-bu-vb-pj2:7.46.13: On that occasion Venerable Upāli was siding with Ajjuka,
pli-tv-bu-vb-pj2:7.46.15: “Ānanda, when one is asked by the owner to assign an estate to so-and-so, and one does so, what has one committed?”
pli-tv-bu-vb-pj2:7.46.16: “One hasn’t committed anything, Sir, not even an act of wrong conduct.”
pli-tv-bu-vb-pj2:7.46.17: “Venerable Ajjuka was asked by the owner to assign an estate to so-and-so, and he did so.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pj2:7.46.18: There’s no offense for Venerable Ajjuka.”
pli-tv-bu-vb-pj2:7.47.1: At that time in Benares, a family that supported Venerable Pilindavaccha was harassed by criminals,
pli-tv-bu-vb-pj2:7.47.2: and two of their children were kidnapped.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pj2:7.47.3: Pilindavaccha brought the children back by his supernormal powers and placed them in a stilt house.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pj2:7.47.4: People saw those children and said,
pli-tv-bu-vb-pj2:7.47.5: “This is the greatness of Venerable Pilindavacchaʼs supernormal powers.”
pli-tv-bu-vb-pj2:7.47.6: and they placed confidence in him.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pj2:7.47.7: But the monks complained and criticized him,
pli-tv-bu-vb-pj2:7.47.8: “How can Venerable Pilindavaccha bring back children who have been kidnapped by criminals?”
pli-tv-bu-vb-pj2:7.47.10: “There’s no offense in the area of supernormal powers for one who possesses them.”
pli-tv-bu-vb-pj2:7.48.1: At one time the two monks Paṇḍaka and Kapila were friends.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pj2:7.48.2: One was staying in a village and one at Kosambī.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pj2:7.48.3: Then, while the first monk was traveling from that village to Kosambī, he had to cross a river. As he did so, a lump of fat that had escaped from the hands of pork-butchers stuck to his foot.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pj2:7.48.4: He took hold of it, thinking, “I’ll give it to the owners.”
pli-tv-bu-vb-pj2:7.48.5: But the owners accused him, saying,
pli-tv-bu-vb-pj2:7.48.7: Then a woman cowherd who had seen him crossing said,
pli-tv-bu-vb-pj2:7.48.9: Thinking he was no longer an ascetic, he had sexual intercourse with her.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pj2:7.48.10: When he arrived at Kosambī, he told the monks,
pli-tv-bu-vb-pj2:7.48.11: and they in turn told the Buddha.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pj2:7.48.12: “There’s no offense entailing expulsion for stealing,
pli-tv-bu-vb-pj2:7.48.13: but there’s an offense entailing expulsion for having sexual intercourse.”
pli-tv-bu-vb-pj2:7.49.1: At that time at Sāgalā, a monk who was a student of Venerable Daḷhika was plagued by discontent. He then took a turban from a shopkeeper and said to Daḷhika,
pli-tv-bu-vb-pj2:7.49.2: “Sir, I’m no longer an ascetic; I’ll disrobe.”
pli-tv-bu-vb-pj2:7.49.5: After getting the turban brought, Venerable Daḷhika had it valued,
pli-tv-bu-vb-pj2:7.49.6: and it was not worth five _māsaka_ coins.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pj2:7.49.10: The second offense entailing expulsion is finished.
